setContent.text:
Evaluating Sources

You can find almost anything on the Internet, but not all of that information is of high quality, and not all of it is appropriate for your assignments.

This tutorial will guide you through the process of evaluating sources of information. The goal is to help you select the best sources for your academic papers and projects.

Five Criteria

When evaluating an information source, there are five things that you should consider.

  1. Author
  2. Review
  3. Date
  4. Sources
  5. Bias

• It should be possible to identify the author. Bonus points if they list their affiliation (university or organization).
  • An author isn’t always a person—it could be an organization or government agency.
  • Check up on the author to make sure they’re trustworthy.

Test Yourself: Author

You‘re writing a paper on childhood lead exposure. You find a report from the Environmental Protection Agency. How trustworthy do you think it is?
setContent.correctResponse: You are correct! The EPA is generally considered a reliable source on environmental toxins.
setContent.incorrectResponse: We disagree. The EPA is generally considered a reliable source on environmental toxins.

setContent.text:
There are different levels of review that a writer’s work could go through before being published.

Peer review is considered the highest level of review. Multiple researchers in the author’s field make suggestions prior to its publication. Most papers in academic journals are peer reviewed.

Editorial review means that an editor has looked over the material before publication. This is better than nothing, but we should remember that editors are susceptible to bias like everyone else. Most books and magazine/newspaper articles are reviewed by editors.

No review happens when an author self-publishes their material. Social media posts, for instance, are generally just written and posted.

setContent.text:
It’s important to think about when something was written. In many cases, you’ll want the latest information on a topic. This is especially true in fields where things change rapidly, like medicine or particle physics.

Newer isn’t always better, though. For instance, if you’re writing about a classic film or doing research for a history paper, older materials would be very good sources.

Test Yourself: Date

You’re writing a paper on recent American elections. You find an article in a major politics journal that addresses this topic. The paper is from 2006. How useful would this source be for your paper?
setContent.correctResponse: Nice job! At best, it might contain some good background information, but there have been a lot of elections since 2006.
setContent.incorrectResponse: We don’t think it’s very useful. At best, it might contain some good background information, but there have been a lot of elections since 2006.

setContent.text:
Research is a conversation. When a scholar takes part in that conversation, as you are doing when you write a paper in college, they need to acknowledge the work that has gone before.

Listing your sources also allows readers to verify your information.

A source that doesn’t cite external information probably isn’t a great choice for your assignment.

Test Yourself: Sources

"… Pippi Longstocking … is a Swedish cultural icon. She is a rebel; an anti-authoritarian, norm-critical girl who defies convention and challenges gender stereotypes (Metcalf 1990). Pippi breaks down the gender barrier, revealing herself as 'the strongest in the world' as she saves lives, tackles boa constrictors and villains, and even out-lifts the world’s strongest man, Mighty Adolph (Edström 2007; Lindgren 1997). Astrid Lindgren created a female character who dominates her world, living according to her own rules and values (Kåreland and Lindh-Munther 2005a; Metcalf 1990)."
From Lynch, L. (2016). Where are all the Pippis? Sex Roles, 75(9-10), 422-433.

Based on the paragraph above, which source does the idea that Pippi Longstocking challenges gender stereotypes come from?

answers.response: No. The idea is credited to Metcalf 1990.
No. The idea is credited to Metcalf 1990.
No. The idea is credited to Metcalf 1990.

setContent.text:
Consider whether there are social, ideological, or financial factors that may influence the author. Is a story on immigration published in a notably left- or right-leaning publication? Is a website about the benefits of a particular nutrient littered with ads for supplements?

Bias doesn’t always mean that a source is bad, but may indicate that you should seek out sources with alternate viewpoints and see how they differ.

Test Yourself: Bias

What is this image trying to convince you of?

answers.text: This graphic is purely fact-based and is not trying to convince the viewer of anything.
answers.response: No, this graphic has a definite viewpoint.

answers.text: Meat production is the primary source of greenhouse gasses.
answers.response: No, the graphic is trying to convince you that meat production is not a significant source of greenhouse gasses.

answers.text: Meat production is not a significant source of greenhouse gasses.
answers.response: Correct! This is the main rhetorical point of the graphic.

answers.text: 30.3% of electricity is used by households.
answers.response: No, the graphic is trying to convince you that meat production is not a significant source of greenhouse gasses.

Test Yourself: Bias

This graphic was created by carnivorecure.com. Do you think this is a reliable source for information about agriculture and greenhouse gasses?

answers.response: No, this website is trying to convince you to eat meat, not provide reliable environmental information.
Correct! This website is trying to convince you to eat meat, not provide reliable environmental information.

setContent.text:
Putting It All Together

Consider all five criteria when you’re choosing your sources. If a source fails on one criterion, but is strong in all the others, it may still be acceptable.
You are writing a paper about the business model of Starbucks. Please order the following sources from most to least appropriate for your project.

items.name: A video published on the Starbucks website called Starbucks Ethical Sourcing of Sustainable Products, 2019
A 2020 peer-reviewed article published in the British Food Journal, "Experiential marketing, brand image and brand loyalty: a case study of Starbucks"
Global Markets Direct SWOT Report on Starbucks published by GlobalData Ltd., accessed via Business Insights Essentials, April 1, 2020
The book <i>Leading the Starbucks Way: 5 Principles for Connecting People with Your Customers, Your Products and Your People" written by Joseph Michelli, 2014

setContent.goodResponse: Your response is very similar to ours! See the numbers above for the way that we ordered the sources.
setContent.badResponse: Not quite. See the numbers above for the way that we ordered the sources.
